awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Chemistry Function, Application, Structure and Theory (FAST): Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Chemistry and Biochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to Georgia Institute of Technology, located in Atlanta, GA, supports the training of 10 undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. This program, funded by the Division of Chemistry engages participants in chemistry research related to Function, Application, Structure, and Theory (FAST). Each undergraduate participant works with an individual faculty member who has an active research group in a thematic area of interest. Other components of the program include team-building activities, regular group meetings, a seminar/workshop series, research symposia, an emphasis on developing a professional social media presence, and field trips to industrial and/or government laboratories. These activities serve to acquaint participants with a broad array of projects, provide them with the opportunity to enhance their presentation skills, and provide a perspective on chemical research in a scholarly, entrepreneurial, economic, and ethical framework. Ultimately, this site promotes the growth of a diverse, well-trained chemistry workforce.

The research projects available for participants span the chemical sciences space. Some of the projects include the study of mechanisms of heme trafficking and signaling, click chemistry in the development of functional materials, electronic structure theory, and mass spectrometry-based protein analysis. The non-research activities provide participants with professional development and training on a variety of topics, including ethics, presentation skills, and research frontiers. This site emphasizes recruitment of students from underrepresented groups in chemistry and provides them with the skills and motivation to embark upon careers in sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
> From 2019-2023, NSF funds supported 27 students in 10-week summer research experiences under the Chemistry Function, Applicarion, Structure, and Theory (FAST) REU Site. The Program  drew students from across the nation. Their home institutions included: Georgia Gwinnett College; U of Florida; Smith College; U of Kentucky; U of Tennessee; U of West Florida; Macalester College; Berry College; Shasta College; Monmouth U; U of California, Irvine, U of Georgia; North Carolina A&T U; Westminster College; Georgetown U; Alabama A&M U; Lander U; U of California, Los Angeles; U of Texas at Dallas; Albany State U; Virginia Tech, Kennesaw State U, U of North Carolina at Wilmington; Savannah State U; U of Wisconsin, Stevens Pointe; and Linfield College. This institution list includes 3 HBCUs, 1 HSI, and 17 Institutions without PhD programs in Chemistry.

> The recent funding cycle (2020-2023) resulting in one peer-reviewed publication and two manuscripts are currently in preparation. 

> Under the award, the Program has been successful in achieving its proposed goals, including:

* High levels of participation by students in underrepresented groups: 11% (3 of 27) of the participants were Hispanic, and 19% (5 of 27) were African-American. Students from Department of Education-designated Minority Institutions [152] accounted for 19% (5 of 27) of participants; 19% (5 of 27) of participants attend Title III and Title V institutions.

* High levels of participation of students from primarily undergraduate institutions: 63% (17 of 27) of participants were from institutions that fall outside of the Carnegie Foundation’s classifications of very high (VH) and high (H) activity research universities (RU).

 * High levels of participation by women: 48% (13 of 27) of the participants were women.

* A high level of success in enhancing a positive view of the research enterprise, as evidenced by the number of students pursuing graduate study in science. Of the participants that have graduated approximately 70% (7 of 10) of participants have embarked on graduate study in the sciences. Four participants have been awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships.

* High levels of participant satisfaction with the program as determined by the end-of-summer surveys. Scale: 1-Strongly Disagree; 4- Strongly Agree.

  • Participation in the REU has increased my interest in doing scientific research. (3.50)         
  • Q49. Participation in the REU has contributed to my motivation to work in a scientific field. (3.35)
  • Q50. At the REU, I made important connection with people who share my research interests. (3.44)
  •  Participation in the REU has contributed to my personal growth. (3.61)
  • I would recommend the REU as a valuable experience to other students. (3.44)

* High levels of faculty satisfaction with the dedication and performance of participants as determined in the end-of-summer advisor survey.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2023
Modified by: Stefan A France
